snippet.authorDisplayName: Just Some Guy On The Internet
snippet.textDisplay:
Oh is that what you thought? You thought *your* signal was coming directly 
from space? No, the network receives the signal from a satellite in space 
and redistributes the signal in different directions. The satellite in 
space simply is made to rotate with the earth at the same pace (Which is 
quite easy since the earth is on the same schedule every day) so that the 
network is *always* receiving the signal. That's usually how it works 
anyways. But hey... I guess its possible your signal was from the satellite 
itself if you were close enough.

Now you answer me this. If the earth is flat, how does a crescent moon or 
lunar eclipses work? If its not the earth's *round* shadow casted on the 
moon (blocking it from the sun light) then what exactly is it and why can 
we not see it?
I could ask you a lot of other question that I know you won't be able to 
answer logically, but we'll just stick with this one for now. Lol

+Steve W The escape velocity of Earth is about 25,000 mph, that's Mach 
32.8, but as long as you maintain or gradually increase your speed and 
maintain direction, you don't suffer any harmful effects at all. Speed in 
space acts in the same way, only one has to be aware of gravity from other 
objects like planets, moons or stars. Traveling at 100,000 mph in space 
wouldn't really be a problem, in relation to where we are in the universe 
and our galaxy, Earths actually moving at about 450,000 MPH. Now as well as 
gravity to keep things on the ground, we have what's called a magnetosphere 
or magnetic field created by the iron core, this traps in the lighter gases 
of our atmosphere. When a core begins to cool, a planet suffers from what's 
called, atmospheric evaporation, pressure loss and water boils away at far 
lower temperatures, all because the magnetosphere starts to fail, allowing 
the lighter gasses into space itself, a typical example of this is 
planet Mars, we can even see a dust trail behind it as it orbits the sun. 
Now as for the Earth being a sphere, well The Earth rotates counter 
clockwise, meaning its rotating eastwards. The sun only rises due East 2 
days per year on the spring and autumn equinoxes. The rest of the year the 
sun rises north or south of due east and sets north or south of due west. 
2,200 years ago there was a man called Eratosthenes, he calculated that at 
a certain time of the day, the sun cast different length shadows at 
different places, proving the Earth was curved, he then used the angles of 
these shadows and the distances between the two points, to calculate the 
circumference of the Earth.

We know the Earth is a sphere because during a lunar eclipse the curve of 
the Earth's shadow is perfectly visible, both when starting and ending. 
Even if the Earth was simply a round disk, people at different places would 
see that curvature at different angles (more closed or more open, depending 
where they stand on that disk), but nope, sorry, people all around the 
globe see the SAME perfect round angled curvature, something ONLY possible 
on a sphere.

Go 10,000 kmts ahead, then make a turn right and go another 10,000, then 
make yet another right turn and go an extra 10,000. Congrats, you are now 
at your starting point, having used a 90 degree triangle. Only, that's 
impossible on a flat surface! You should have walked an incomplete square. 
That is only possible over a spherical surface and is the ULTIMATE proof 
the Earth is spherical. If you don't trust this example, you now also have 
to debunk Geometry... can you do it?

The following research proves the earth is a sphere:
LUNAR ECLIPSE
During lunar eclipses (when the Earth’s orbit places it directly between 
the Sun and the Moon, creating a shadow in the process), the shadow on the 
Moon’s surface is round. This shadow is the Earth’s, and it’s a great clue 
on the spherical shape of the Earth. The consistent oval-shadow it produces 
in each and every lunar eclipse proves that the earth is not only round but 
spherical –  not flat.

HORIZON
 If your at the beach and stare off into the horizon at approaching ships, 
they don't just "appear" out of the horizon (like they should have if the 
world was flat), but rather the ships look like they emerge from beneath 
the sea. The reason ships appear as if they “emerge from the waves” is 
because the world is not flat: it’s round.

STARS
The farther you go from the equator, the farther the ‘known’ constellations 
go towards the horizon, and are replaced by different stars. This would not 
happen if the world was flat.

SHADOWS
If you put a stick in the ground, it will produce a shadow. The shadow 
moves as time passes (which is the principle for ancient Shadow Clocks). If 
the world had been flat, then two sticks in different locations would 
produce the same shadow. But they don’t. This is because the earth is 
round, and not flat.

TIMEZONES
If the time in New York is 12:00 pm, the sun is in the middle of the sky. 
In Beijing, it’s 12:00am, midnight, and the sun is nowhere to be found.
In Adelaide, Australia, it is 1:30am. More than 13 hours ahead. There, the 
sunset is long gone. This can only be explained if the world is round, and 
rotating around its own axis. At a certain point when the sun is shining on 
one part of the Earth, the opposite side is dark, and vise versa. That 
allows for time differences and timezones, specifically ones that are 
larger than 12 hours.
